The open nature of the editing model has been central to most criticism of Wikipedia. For example, at any point, a reader of an article cannot be certain, without consulting its "history" page, whether or not the article she is reading has been vandalized.<!-- An encyclopedia Britannica editor once described this by saying that Wikipedia is like a public toilet; you don't know who has used it before you are going to use it.{{Fact|date=October 2008}}--> Critics argue that non-expert editing undermines quality.
